qas.question: What do the hole walls in two-layer PCBs have to be before they can be electroplated?
What's the minimum number of layers a PCB can have to be considered "multi-layer"?
What process does a multi-layer PCB usually undergo before plating to make sure the layers have good connectivity with each other?
What type of boards undergo the etch-back process?
Etch-back removes glass fibers and what other material?
What connects the conducting layers of the PAB?
Smears are removed with a chemical smear what?
The process used on low-reliability boards is called what?
What becomes integral with the deposited silver?

context: The hole walls for boards with two or more layers can be made <a0_0>conductive<a0_0/> and then electroplated with copper to form plated-through holes.  These <b5_0>holes<b5_0/> electrically connect the conducting layers of the PCB. For multi-layer boards, those with <a1_0>three<a1_0/> layers or more, drilling typically produces a smear of the high temperature decomposition products of bonding agent in the laminate system. Before the holes can be plated through, this smear must be removed by a chemical de-smear <b6_0>process<b6_0/>, or by plasma-etch. The <a2_0>de-smear<a2_0/> process ensures that a good connection is made to the copper layers when the hole is plated through. On <a3_0>high reliability<a3_0/> boards a process called <b7_0>etch-back<b7_0/> is performed chemically with a potassium permanganate based etchant or plasma. The etch-back removes <a4_0><b8_0>resin<a4_0/> and the glass fibers<b8_0/> so that the copper layers extend into the hole and as <b9_0>the hole<b9_0/> is plated become integral with the deposited copper.
